thread.title: Rag pile caused brush fire that threatened 3 houses in W. Seattle |
thread.title_full: Rag pile caused brush fire that threatened 3 houses in W. Seattle | The Seattle Times

author: Seattle Times staff
title: Rag pile caused brush fire that threatened 3 houses in W. Seattle |
text:
A pile of wood-stain-soaked rags caused a brush fire that threatened three homes in the Arroyo Beach neighborhood in West Seattle on Monday afternoon, officials said.
Seattle Fire spokesman Kyle Moore said firefighters were called to the 10900 block of 39th Avenue Southwest at 1:14 p.m.
Around 2:30 p.m., Moore said the fire was out, but firefighters were still putting out hot spots. Moore said at one point the fire was within 75 yards of a home. There were no reported injuries, he said.
The fire was caused by a pile of rags being used to stain wood furniture, left in a backyard under the hot sun. Moore said these kind of staining rags “can spontaneously combust, which they did.” He said sunlight can speed up the reaction.
Most Read Stories Black Lives Matter protesters shut down Bernie Sanders; later rally draws 15,000 60 years ago: The famous Boeing 707 prototype barrel roll over Lake Washington Seahawks' 53-man roster projection, post-scrimmage edition Seahawks rewarded for sticking to their salary-cap plan Condition of boy hurt in fall at Taylor Swift concert improves Moore said the fire got close to the home but “ended up burning upwards” toward a hill rather than “backwards toward the house.”
The fire burned about 2 acres, he said.
Jennifer Sullivan: 206-464-8294 or jensullivan@seattletimes.com . On Twitter @SeattleSullivan .
